user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_read_map_attr:
```c
static int metal_uio_read_map_attr(struct linux_device *ldev,
				   unsigned int index,
				   const char *name,
				   unsigned long *value)
{
	const char *cls = ldev->cls_path;
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	char path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX];
	int result;

	result = snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/maps/map%u/%s", cls, index, name);
	if (result >= (int)sizeof(path))
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	attr = sysfs_open_attribute(path);
	if (!attr || sysfs_read_attribute(attr) != 0) {
		sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
		return -errno;
	}

	*value = strtoul(attr->value, NULL, 0);

	sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_read_map_attr:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the function metal_uio_read_map_attr and the related struct. I found no compiler-specific language extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (for example: __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values (&&label), zero-length array extensions, or other vendor-specific keywords). The array definitions (char path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX]; and fixed-size members in struct linux_device) use macros/constant sizes — not compiler-specific extensions. Standard library calls (snprintf, strtoul) and use of errno/NULL are standard C and not extensions. The Linux-style negative errno returns (e.g. -EOVERFLOW, -errno) are coding conventions, not language extensions. Therefore there are no code fragments that need to be reported for Rule 1.2.
